title: Introducing: Evening Man
content:
I’m finding it really difficult to pin my finger on exactly what it is that I like so much about Washington’s Evening Man aka Paul Erik Lipp.

His newest release In Space is a myriad of twisted synths, outlandishly auto-tuned vocals and pop songwriting worthy of a diploma. Eccentric and at times slightly abrasive, the nine tracks that comprise the release are each individually tailored to perspire a differing section of Lipp’s personality. Be it the 80’s squelchy tenebrosity of In Movies or the screeched line “But that doesn’t mean I won’t stay here anyway.” unearthed in Glass Beneath The Skin, Evening Man is the music of a collection of a vulnerable yet cock-sure musician.

Sonically, the vocals bring up memories of Elbow’s Guy Garvey  whilst the instrumentation is part Duran Duran, part Depeche Mode, as it swings between menacing and luxuriously upbeat. My personal highlight, the soundtrack worthy I Can’t Be Your Man finds it’s roots amongst folk-pop yet spreads his branches into the far more exciting and emotionally unstable realms. The way you stand there in the light, like I never could have found you. 
You could evaporate in night. You know I’m gonna have to… Check out the full release below, and keep up with Evening Man via Facebook.
